column1: Lobnya (Russian: Ло́бня) is a town in Moscow Oblast
column3: located 30 kilometers (19 mi) north west of Moscow. Population: 74

column1: == History ==
Lobnya was founded in 1902 and granted town status in 1961.
=== Krasnaya Polyana in the Battle of Moscow ===

The German attack starting the Battle of Moscow (code-named ‘Operation Typhoon’) began on October 2 1941. The attack on a broad front brought German forces to occupy the village of Krasnaya Polyana (now in the town of Lobnya) to Moscow's North West. Krasnaya Polyana was taken on November 30. This is accepted by many as the closest point occupied by German forces to Moscow. Less accepted is that this is the closest point visited by Germans to Moscow in the campaign.Many sources state that at least one German army patrol visited nearby Khimki. Similarly many sources state Khimki as the closest point the Germans reached to Moscow (Khimki at the time was 8 kilometres (5.0 mi) from the edge of Moscow). Among the sources stating the Germans reached Khimki the details of the date and unit involved are inconsistent and disputed. One story of events asserts a skirmish took place in Khimki on October 16 at the Leningradskoye Shosse bridge involving a German motorcycle unit. Another account is a patrol reached Khimki around November 30 or early December before returning to its main unit without combat. The dates mentioned for this second account vary. A myth surrounding this is that the Germans would have been able to see the Kremlin in the distance from Khimki.

The Soviet Army counter offensive for "removing the immediate threat to Moscow" started on December 5 on the North-Western Front (the area around Krasnaya Polyana and Lobnya North West of Moscow). The South-Western Front and Western Fronts began their offensives on December 6. The German forces were driven back. Moscow was never under such close land threat again during the war.

column1: == Architecture ==
The environs are rich in architectural monuments
column2: such as the Neo-Gothic estate of Marfino located 9 kilometers (5.6 mi) to the northeast
column3: which was laid out by Field Marshal Pyotr Saltykov in the 1770s but was extensively modernized by Count Panin in 1837–1839. The palace is Gothic in style
column4: scored to resemble a medieval castle; a flight of stairs connects it with a white-stone wharf by the river
column5: decorated with statues of griffins. To the west from the palace stands the Petrine Baroque church of the Virgin's Nativity (1701–1707). There are also a Gothic bridge
column7: and two English parks with picturesque rotundas.

column1: Within two kilometers from Marfino is the manor of Nikolskoye-Prozorovskoye
column2: which contains a Neo-Baroque country house of Field Marshal Prozorovsky and a Neoclassical church of St. Nicholas
column3: built in the 1790s. Nearby is Rozhdestveno-Suvorovo
column4: where the five-domed church of the Virgin's Nativity was built by Princes Baryatinsky at the turn of the 18th century. In 1773
column5: the estate passed to Alexander Suvorov's father
column7: a general-in-chief who is buried in the church.

column1: The oldest building in the vicinity is the five-domed four-pillared apseless Trinity Church in Chashnikovo (four kilometers from Lobnya). Its elegant Italianate decor
column2: reminiscent of the Chudov Monastery cathedral
column3: dates the church to the early years of the 16th century
column4: when such Italian architects as Aloisio the New were active in Russia. The church was first documented in 1585
column5: when Chashnikovo was owned by Nikita Romanov
column6: grandfather of Tsar Mikhail I. By the end of the 17th century
column7: the estate had passed to Lev Naryshkin
column8: maternal uncle of Peter the Great
column9: who added a bell tower and had the church's decor updated to answer his own Naryshkin Baroque tastes.

column1: Other well-known villages in the vicinity of Lobnya are Zhostovo (seven kilometers to the northeast) and Fedoskino (ten kilometers to the east)
column2: renowned for their traditional folk crafts of Zhostovo painting and Fedoskino miniature
